text: do you go to restaurants and order the
braised rabbit but then you think I'm a
little hesitant to make rabbit at home
don't be because rabbit is no harder to
cook than chicken and it is so tender
when it's done right and earthy and just
unlike any other meat just like when you
cook chicken you want to flavor rabbit
with something pretty powerful because
rabbit will take on the flavors of
whatever aromatics you use with it so
I'm gonna use oregano and I have
rosemary and garlic of course because
you have to have garlic and then I'm
just gonna let it sit for an hour so
that it has a chance to absorb the
seasonings the longer you let this sit
the more of the flavors of the
ingredients it will absorb up to a point
because the salt will start to break
down the rabbit meat so you want to do
this either an hour ahead or you can put
it in the fridge and do it the night
before
once that's sat for a while I'm just
going to brown off the pieces really
well gotta get your pan nice and hot add
a little olive oil if this looks like a
very small amount of oil for me it is
but that's because I'm going to add lots
of butter later so I'm choosing my fats
carefully here rabbit it's a very lean
meat so it wants you to add fat to it
this is the only time your rabbits gonna
be able to take on any color so really
let it get golden on both sides because
it's in the oven for just 10 minutes or
so it doesn't take on color at that
point so do it now if the garlic starts
to look a little Brown before the
rabbits finish browning just take the
garlic and plop it right on top put the
little rabbit pieces and that will keep
it from burning that is a good tip
when your rabbit is brown add some
thinly sliced lemon then I have olives
sliced olives and remember I mentioned
the butter it's gonna add half of the
butter now and then half to thicken the
sauce at the end and then lastly I have
some wine that I reduced on the stove I
have made this recipe using white wine
I've made it using red wine
use whatever bottle you happen to have
open or that you want to drink that
night with dinner they're both good
cover it and then this goes in the oven
it's just gonna go for five minutes and
then I'm gonna add feta cheese you can
use really any kind of feta I like
French feta because I think it's the
creamiest it makes the richest sauce but
Greek feta is great too Bulgarian and
then this goes back in the oven another
10 ish minutes make sure that it's done
that looks pretty done you can do the
same kind of test that you do for any
meat just kind of push it and when it
feels firm like that it is done you
don't want to over cook rabbit though so
do watch it carefully just keep checking
it now I'm just gonna add a little more
butter into the pan sauce just to finish
it off
save it rabbits not that hard if this
dish looks good to you but you know in
your heart that you're never gonna cook
a rabbit you can do it with chicken I
give you permission but it really is
better with rabbit
